caption:
“The climate crisis we’re facing is an opportunity for people to recognize the power of Indigenous knowledge and to recognize that tribes have the ability, if we could empower them, to help co-manage the environment up and down the state.”—Kouslaa Kessler-Mata, Yak Tityu Tityu Yak Tiłhini Northern Chumash and Yokut
 
Along California’s windswept coast, in the rocky crags and tide pools, California Indians (as this group prefers to be called) have subsisted for millennia on fish, abalone and seaweed, never taking more than can be naturally replaced. The effects of the climate crisis combined with unsustainable harvesting by non-native people have decimated their traditional food sources. Today, despite regulations, they continue the hard work of subsistence gathering and keep their cultural practices alive.

caption:
A decade ago, sisters Sonya and Nina Montenegro (@thefarwoods) became aware of the dark side of fashion—how the majority of our clothes have come at the cost of slave labor, pollution, suffering and waste. They saw mending as one response—an act of healing, acknowledging and honoring the labor and resources that went into making the garment. In 2016, the sisters launched The Far Woods to share mending tutorials far and wide. And, in 2020, they wrote and illustrated Mending Life: A Handbook for Repairing Clothes and Hearts.⁠
⁠

caption:
In 1972, Yvon Chouinard and Tom Frost opened the Chouinard Equipment catalog by urging climbers to stop using pitons, their best-selling product, in order to protect the rock. The clean climbing principles they outlined interrogated the highest ideals of climbing and instilled the values that drive Patagonia to this day. We're commemorating the 50th anniversary of the ’72 catalog by republishing their essay in full, so that it may inspire a new generation of climbers and help renew our own commitments: to putting style over summit, to the climbing community, and to the planet we’re still working to save.⁠
⁠
Read it through the link in bio.⁠
Photo: Tom Frost

caption:
On May 15, 1994, 8-year-old Denis Tuzinovic (@den07) and his mom fled Bosnia and Herzegovina to escape war and genocide. They lived in refugee camps across Europe before settling in the US. Support from community organizations along the way provided Denis opportunities to experience wilderness areas—trips his family would never have been able to afford. “I didn’t know what it looked like yet,” Denis recalls, “but I knew I wanted to do something involving community activism and the outdoors.”⁠
⁠
Read “Gdje Su Svi Dobrodošli (Where Everyone is Welcome)” through the link in bio.⁠

caption:
In 1972, Chouinard Equipment bet the farm, urging climbers to stop using the company’s best-selling product to protect the rock. ​
​
Clean climbing—making the switch from pitons to chocks—fundamentally changed both the art of the sport and the ethos of the community. It was climbing’s first environmental movement and instilled the values that drive Patagonia to this day. But more importantly, it was a challenge—what were climbers capable of achieving in order to protect the places they love?​
​
50 years later, we’re asking that question again. ​
​
Celebrating the ethic laid down in the 1972 Chouinard Equipment catalog means bringing humility, intention and creativity to every climb and inviting all climbers to build this legacy with us. It’s a commitment to the sport we love, to everything we make and to the planet we’re still working to save.​
​
Visit the link in our bio for more.

caption:
Falconer Shawn Hayes (@shawnhayesfalconry) leads a life of devotion—to both his falcons and to the mountains and prairies beneath their wings. For Shawn, the ancient practice of falconry is more than a deep partnership with raptors: it’s become his life’s work. Through his skill and finesse with these birds of prey he’s carved a space for himself in a culture where people of color haven’t always been welcome. Shawn’s role as an American falconry ambassador has taken him to the far reaches of the globe, through strongholds of tradition and conservation. This film is about more than what humans can train birds to do—it’s about what those birds can teach us about living in partnership with wild creatures and wild places. 
 
Film by: Brett Marty (@brettmarty) & Josh Izenberg (@onlyhumanfilm) from Speculative Films (@speculativefilms)
